content.description: A simple problem working through some good angled ledges into a topout.
content.location: The left most problem at Jungle Pond next to Microscopic Multipitch.  Sit start on the left corner and pull up into a deep angled edge topping out from there.

content.description: Another traversing problem with a varied beta at the crux in the middle finishing with some jug cracks and positive rounded holds.
content.location: Start on the main jug in the middle of the wall right above the clear crack. Traverse your way right to a crux sequence with different possible beta out to a deep flake.  Pull up to a deep crack followed by a reachy move to an incut sloper and up through the topout.

content.description: A smooth little problem working up some angled crimps up the side of the boulder into a solid ledge, which you then traverse into an easy mantle topout.
content.location: Found to the right of Raise the Roof and Power Crack. On the right side of this boulder you will see 3 angled crimps that flow into the top ledge. Start on the lowest two.

content.description: Another fun unique problem that has you working your way up and over a small roof through some good slopers and fun feet.
content.location: Found below the main wall and slightly to the right you will see a pair of slightly over handing boulders.  This problems barely sit start can be found on the ledge (approximately chest height) of the right boulder.

content.description: A very crammed crack problem that will be difficult to not dab with pad protection. Work your way through some fist and hand jams to the same topout as Sidewinder. If you're in the mood for a small crack climb it does offer some decent jams if you can fit.
content.location: Located below the main wall to the right of Raise the Roof, trapped in the corner behind the tree.

content.description: A smooth problem through a clear low crimp line up through some positive jugs
content.location: Start as far right as possible on the crimp line (sitting on the boulder) and traverse left to the end of it.  From there, make your way up to a good sloper and trek right up through some jugs and a topout as you wish.

climbs.name: Out of the Dark and Into the Light

content.description: Fun slightly unique problem making a big first move to huge ledges and a solid topout.
content.location: Found below the main wall and slightly to the right you will see a pair of slightly over hanging boulders.  This problems start can be found under the left boulder.

content.description: A clique dyno problem because why not get a little jumping in.
content.location: Start to the left of the clear crimp line on a jug and use good feet to fire up and slightly to the right to a jug topout.

content.description: Work your way through some awkward, lowrider movement to the right arete.  Topout from there.
content.location: On the left most end of Jungle Pond, but on the right side of that rock next to Welcome Problem.

content.description: A smooth simple problem with low feet and not much else, eventually traversing up to a dish and rounded topout.
content.protection: Pads and good spotter or two. The landing is a sloping slab that would dump you into scree if you bounce
content.location: Start under the overhang on the smallest crimp and traverse left using either good low feet or smearing to the jug above the clear vertical crack. From there reach up and over to a rounded jug and committing topout.

climbs.name: Inshallah AKA a fanciful hope that the waking nightmare of the Trump presidency will end in joy.

content.description: Sit start at the base of the crack with 3 sidepull options and feet in low seam. Move up and left to the obvious break, and up and over the arete/buttress to topout. Stacking pads for the sit definitely reduces the grade.
content.location: In the center of the nice clean wall, find the vertical crack with 3 distinct sidepulls.

content.description: Work your way through some interesting movement up a rounded arete and a slick sidepull rail.
content.location: Found on the left side of the Jungle Pond area on the large ledge with your feet underneath, just right of Blood Sucker.  Work your way straight up the arete through the rounded topout.

content.description: Short but good. Sit start with both hands jammed in the low horizontal crack, feet pasted. head straight up making use of the big arcing hold for your right and a high crimp for your left. Top out with a mantle (no grabbing the tree!)
content.location: All the way down about 200 feet to the right, 10-12 feet right of Bubble Head

content.description: This problem has clearly been done before so I will keep it unnamed until it is claimed. Similar to the other unnamed on the left side of the main wall with a low start.
content.location: Start on the low crimp where the other V3 crimp line traverses above. Make a large first move into the crimp line and finish straight up.

content.description: A slightly techy problem with potentially interesting foot beta working through the vertical crack up to the right. Originally started from the incut jug, with further cleaning, you can now start more to the left from the shelf with your feet under the roof, adding just enough pump to maybe bump the grade up to V5
content.location: Begin on the big jug start same as Monkey Jump and utilize the verticals crack sidepulls to traverse right into the end of the crimp line, up to the good sloper and up through the jugs out right.

content.description: A couple hundred feet to the right of the initial face of the ledge are some more scattered problems. They are mostly pretty short or involve eliminates, but some have cool holds and fun movement. This is one of the better ones, with cool slopers and core moves.Sit down start with hands on the big hand ledge that angles up and right under the bulge. Pull on and do a couple moves right to the horns (the big leaning  block at the base is off for your feet), then head straight out the bulge using the the bulbous sidepull with your left and up to a series of slopers that angle you left until you can pop back to  an incut horizontal and top out. I took a star off because it is a little contrived to not use the horizontal to the right of the slopers, but it makes the problem much better.
content.location: Head right along the ledge system about 200 feet from the initial face. It should be fairly obvious from the topo photo

content.description: If I posted a picture you would laugh, but it actually makes a good easy warmup. To the right of Bubble Head, on the other side of the tree, from the break, hand traverse right along the top on nice big slopers , finishing with the mantle finish of H&TS.
content.location: Far right end of Jungle Pond, in the Bubble Head  area

content.description: This is a compression problem with some gritty left hand holds and home to an army of mosquitos in the summer.
content.location: Located on the left end of Jungle Beach start sitting with two good opposing holds.  Slap your way up the main face, eventually bringing your feet over to the right face allowing you to continue up through the topout.

content.description: The contrived but far more enjoyable version of Coyote Drippings.  Perform the same problem as Coyote, but do not use the rounded arete at all, only staying on the face using the sidepull rail. This will incorporate super fun technical movement that I think is far more enjoyable.
content.location: Found on the left side of the Jungle Pond area on the large ledge with your feet underneath, just right of Blood Sucker.  Work your way straight up the arete using only sidepulls to the rounded topout.

content.description: This area consists of a long bouldering ledge facing west on one of the shallow ridges that run perpendicular to the road east of the pond. The wall itself is at least 75-100 feet long, but the majority of the clear climbing section is within the middle portion of the wall. If you continue south there are further scattered developed lines. There are still possibilities for further development. Keep an eye out for poison ivy.
